job_title: Doctoral Teaching Fellow in Springfield, MA
pros: The community at the college is encouraging and supportive, overall. The student body seem reasonably accepting, with minimal bullying, bigotry, or strife around the campus (as far as I've been able to observe). The faculty seem like fundamentally decent people, and there's a warmth here that isn't always found in higher ed -- whether in smaller liberal arts/teaching schools like this one, or at larger research institutions. The work environment is fairly healthy in terms of the kind of work that is usually expected of grad student workers, provided one looks at this independently of the pay that is provided.
cons: Pay is pretty awful, particularly in light of the fact that *zero* meaningful benefits are provided. Unlike at many other schools, Springfield College doesn't provide health insurance to its graduate assistants and fellows (despite the fact that Massachusetts law requires full-time students to carry health insurance). When the pay is already so low, this leaves many students in the untenable position of having a mid-4-figure sum that's supposed to last them all year (and this is after the recent raises and assuming a student gets one of the "higher-paying" fellowships). However tight the budget is for the school, this is an egregious problem that absolutely has to be addressed if the college expects to attract more students who are competitive and who have enough self-respect to want to live with dignity.

review_title: Hard to find a place that cares less about its employees than Springfield College
pros:
- Generous amount of time off (22 days, plus a week between Christmas and New Year's)
- Great mission, great students
- Some of the people who work in the "lower ranks" (aka not top-level managers) are truly smart, talented, and inspiring
cons:
- Mission of the college (giving back to others) is touted, but not put into practice 
- Little room for growth or professional development
- "Merit-based" raises do not exist. Employees are given an annual 2% "cost of living" wage. However, upper management sees raises of more than 2% each year. Some also receive bonuses and are reimbursed for things such as their cars and cell phones. 
- Wages are not competitive at all, despite every single member of upper management or "PLT" (yes, they gave themselves a nickname) making more than six figures. It is well-known that SC does not pay well, especially for those early in their career, and they are currently undergoing a “compensation study”—the first in 20 years—because the situation is so dire. Most employees make less than $50,000. Many SC job searches come back as “failed” because the compensation is too low. 
- Often suffers from budget mismanagement
- Good work often goes unacknowledged or rewarded
- Managers are not well-trained but often get promoted/receive raises
- Suffers from massive administrative bloat

pros:
Nice athletic facilities due to the schools emphasis on sports and athletics.
Starbucks and Dunking Donuts on Campus so that you can make it through the hell-ish work day.
cons:
The school takes advantage of faculty members by forcing them to perform 7 jobs in one without receiving any gratitude or recognition for work performed. Tenured faculty do nothing while non-tenured faculty have to pick up all their slack. 
Raises and promotions are nonexistent. Awful benefits and pay is crap. 
The school puts a lot of emphasis on student athletics so do not expect much in terms of academic achievement from students.  
There is no push for research or publications by professors. They actually steer you away from research so as to have all focus be on student hand-holding. 

Assistant Professors disappear after the first year because of the awful work life balance and slave labor environment. Tenured faculty members remain there because they have no other options after not having done any research or publications.

I would not even recommend my worst enemy to accept a job at Springfield College.
